overview.short: Clostridioides difficile is a Gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming rod and a leading cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhoea and pseudomembranous colitis.
overview.clinical_context: Classically associated with recent antibiotic exposure, healthcare settings, and detection of toxin production.

species_markers.notes: Motility supports C. difficile in context, but is not exclusive among anaerobic rods.
Indole negativity helps distinguish from certain other clostridial anaerobes.
Growth on selective media supports isolation/confirmation in appropriate clinical context.

common_confusions.reason: Same genus and broad anaerobic spore-forming profile; requires higher-resolution confirmation.
Many species are anaerobic spore-forming rods with overlapping biochemical reactions.

when_to_question_identification: Lack of anaerobic growth suggests an aerobe/facultative organism rather than Clostridioides.
Non-spore-forming phenotype argues strongly against C. difficile.
If clinical context is not gastrointestinal/antibiotic-associated, consider alternative anaerobes.

recommended_next_tests.test: Toxin A/B detection (EIA) or GDH + toxin algorithm
recommended_next_tests.reason: Toxin detection is central to clinically relevant identification of toxigenic C. difficile.
recommended_next_tests.api_kit_example: C. difficile GDH + toxin A/B rapid immunoassay kits (varies by lab supplier).

recommended_next_tests.reason: High sensitivity confirmation for toxigenic strains when algorithm indicates.
recommended_next_tests.api_kit_example: C. difficile toxin gene NAAT/PCR assay kits (platform-dependent).

recommended_next_tests.reason: Reliable organism identification; toxin status still requires toxin/NAAT testing.
